children.name: to make sth look, taste, or seem much less good
spoil b1
children.definition: spoil/spɔɪl/
examples: ▪ a badly positioned path can spoil the appearance of a garden.
▪ the power station is extremely ugly, and it spoils the view of the sea.
spoil something for somebody
▪ new housing developments are spoiling the countryside for everyone.

children.name: ruin b2
children.definition: ruin/ˈruːɪn, ˈruːən/  to completely spoil something:
examples: ▪ the rain had ruined her best velvet skirt.
▪ don’t use harsh soap to wash your face. it will ruin your skin
.▪ protestors say that the proposed new airport will ruin this peaceful area.

children.name: mar x
children.definition: mar /mɑːʳ/  written to spoil the appearance or beauty of a person or place:
examples: ▪ electricity cables and oil pipelines mar many of the world’s most beautiful landscapes.
▪ he had handsome arabic features, marred by a long scar across his face.

children.name: detract from x
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive phrasal verb not usually in progressive]
children.definition: detract from/dɪˈtrækt frɒm/  to slightly spoil something that is generally very good, beautiful, impressive etc:
examples: ▪ even a bruise on her cheekbone did not detract from her beauty.
▪ the proposed building would detract from the character of the surrounding area.

children.name: to spoil the good opinion that people have of sb
spoil sb’s image
children.definition: spoil somebody’s image/ˌspɔɪl somebodyˈs ˈɪmɪdʒ/  to spoil the idea that people have about someone, especially a famous person who is often on television, in newspapers and magazines etc:
examples: ▪ the star’s cleancut image has been spoiled by accusations of gambling and drug-taking.

children.name: damage sb’s reputation
children.definition: damage somebody’s reputation/ˌdæmɪdʒ somebodyˈs repjʊˈteɪʃən/  to make people no longer have a good opinion about someone, especially a politician or someone with an important job:
examples: ▪ my main concern was to prevent this incident from damaging my reputation.

children.name: damaging
children.definition: /ˈdæmɪdʒɪŋ/  containing information about someone’s dishonest or immoral behaviour, which damages the good opinion that people have of them:
examples: ▪ we can’t risk any damaging scandals just before a presidential election.
▪ his career had been ruined by the sensational and damaging stories that appeared in the popular press.
damaging to
▪ the recent court cases have been very damaging to the public image of the medical profession.

children.name: smear campaign
children.definition: /ˈsmɪəʳ kæmˌpeɪn/  when an organization such as a political party or newspaper deliberately tries to find out and tell people about bad things someone in a public position has done, for example so that people are less likely to vote for them:
examples: ▪ the magistrates who investigated his business empire have been made victims of a smear campaign.
smear campaign against
▪ he called on people to ignore what he called a smear campaign against the government.

children.name: discredit
children.definition: /dɪsˈkredɪt, dɪsˈkredət/  to damage the good opinion that people have of a person or organization, especially when this is done deliberately and in order to get an advantage:
examples: ▪ it was a blatant attempt to discredit the prime minister.
▪ there were reports that his campaign team had been trying to dig up information that might discredit his rival.

children.name: to spoil sb’s work or plans
spoil b1
children.definition: spoil/spɔɪl/
examples: ▪ don’t let me spoil your plans.
▪ this scandal could spoil the senator’s chances of becoming president.
▪ we were going to get married, but then war broke out and spoiled everything.
spoil something for somebody
▪ starting a family so soon would definitely spoil her career prospects for her.

children.name: ruin b2
children.definition: ruin/ˈruːɪn, ˈruːən/  to completely spoil what someone has been trying to do:
examples: ▪ surely you don’t want to ruin all our good work, do you?
▪ serious in-fighting ruined the conservatives’ chances of winning the election.

children.name: mess up b2
children.definition: mess up informal to spoil sth important or sth that has been carefully planned:
examples: the travel agents messed up the arrangements and there was no room for us at the hotel
we secretly organized a party for her, but then bill messed everything up by telling her about it.

children.name: undermine c2
children.definition: undermine/ˌʌndəʳˈmaɪn/  to spoil something that has taken a long time to develop:
examples: ▪ the kidnappings undermined several months of delicate peace negotiations.
▪ the us was accused of undermining international efforts to combat global warming.

children.name: screw up x
children.definition: screw up/ˌskruː ˈʌp/  informal to completely spoil something such as a plan, especially by doing something stupid:
examples: ▪ someone screwed up and what was supposed to be a confidential email was copies to everyone in the company.
screw something up
▪ i can’t trust you to do anything right can i? you always manage to screw things up.
screw up something
▪ there was no way he was going to allow her to screw up his plans.

children.name: sabotage x
children.definition: sabotage/ˈsæbətɑːʒ/  to deliberately spoil someone’s plans or arrangements because you do not want them to succeed:
examples: ▪ her father sabotaged her acting ambitions by refusing to let her go to drama school.
▪ the attack is being seen as a deliberate attempt to sabotage the peace talks

children.name: throw a spanner in the works x
children.definition: throw a spanner in the worksbritish/throw amonkey wrench in/into something american /ˌθrəʊ ə ˈspænəʳ ɪn ðə ˌwɜːʳks, ˌθrəʊ ə ˈmʌŋki rentʃ ɪn, ɪntə something/  informal to unexpectedly do something that prevents a plan or process from continuing or succeeding:
examples: ▪ ‘he won’t lend us the money after all.’ ‘well, that’s really thrown a spanner in the works, hasn’t it?’
▪ the president’s veto threw a wrench into a program that had already been approved by a big majority of the congress.

children.name: pour cold water on x
children.definition: pour cold water on/ˌpɔːʳ kəʊld ˈwɔːtər ɒn/  to spoil someone’s plan, suggestion, or attitude towards something, by saying something that makes it seem less attractive or less likely to succeed:
examples: ▪ her mother had poured cold water on the whole idea of eva going to africa
.▪ the committee’s final report, just published, pours cold water on government proposals for helping the unemployed.

children.name: wet blanket x
children.definition: wet blanket /ˌwet ˈblæŋktǁˈwet ˌblæŋ-/  informal someone who spoils a happy event for other people, especially by refusing to join in with everyone else:
examples: ▪ stop being a wet blanket and come and dance.
▪ does he have to come on vacation with us? he’s such a wet blanket!

children.name: spoiler x
children.definition: spoiler/ˈspɔɪləʳ/  someone who deliberately spoils someone else’s enjoyment, happiness, or plans:
examples: ▪ my ex-husband was a real spoiler who turned every happy event into a nightmare.

children.name: spoilsport x
children.definition: spoilsport/ˈspɔɪlspɔːʳt/  informal someone who spoils other people’s enjoyment, especially by trying to prevent them from doing something:
examples: ▪ ‘i don’t think we should go in there - someone might see us.’ ‘oh, don’t be such a spoilsport - come on!’

children.name: party pooper x
children.definition: party pooper /ˈpɑːʳti ˌpuːpəʳ/  spoken informal sb who spoils other people’s fun, for example by saying that they should not be doing what they are doing:
examples: ▪ when he said it was time to wind things up, the others accused him of being a party pooper.

children.name: killjoy x
children.definition: killjoy/ˈkɪldʒɔɪ/  informal someone who disapproves of things that other people enjoy and who tries to stop them enjoying themselves: kẻ phá đám
examples: ▪ we wanted to do a sponsored dance after work but those killjoys in head office wouldn’t let us.

children.name: to spoil a relationship or friendship
spoil b1
children.definition: spoil/spɔɪl/
examples: ▪ his jealousy spoiled their relationship, and she left him after a few months.
▪ the assassination attempt has definitely spoilt the previously positive atmosphere between the opposing parties.

children.name: sour x
children.definition: sour/saʊəʳ/  to spoil a friendly relationship between people, especially when this happens gradually:
examples: ▪ the affair did not seem to have soured their friendship.
▪ the global trend towards higher taxation on fuel consumption is souring relations with leading oil-producing states.
▪ the incident was serious enough to sour the atmosphere for weeks.

children.name: poison x
children.definition: poison/ˈpɔɪzən/  to spoil a relationship, especially a close one, by causing a situation in which people can no longer trust each other:
examples: ▪ our marriage was poisoned by mistrust, deceit and jealousy.

children.name: destroy b1
children.definition: destroy/dɪˈstrɔɪ/  to completely spoil a relationship or friendship:
examples: ▪ i don’t want this to destroy our friendship.
▪ her feelings of self-doubt had destroyed every relationship that she had ever had.

children.name: unspoiled c1
children.definition: unspoiled/unspoilt/ˌʌnˈspɔɪld◂, ˌʌnˈspɔɪlt◂/  a place or area that isunspoiledorunspoilthas not been spoiled by being changed:
examples: ▪ this is one of africa’s oldest remaining areas of unspoilt rainforest.
▪ an unspoiled fishing village on the mediterranean coast
▪ it was only by the grace of god that the village remained largely unspoiled.

children.name: unblemished x
children.definition: unblemished/ˌʌnˈblemɪʃt/  not spoiled in any way - use this about the opinion people have of someone or how well someone has done their job:
examples: ▪ lord edwards is retiring after an unblemished career that has lasted thirty years.
▪ an unblemished record of service to the community
▪ she is a woman with an unblemished reputation of fairness and competence.

children.name: o make an event less enjoyable or successful
spoil
children.definition: /spɔɪl/
examples: ▪ the bad weather completely spoiled our holiday.
▪ why did you have to invite jerry? you’ve spoiled the whole weekend.
▪ this was her moment of glory, and she wasn’t going to let anyone spoil it.
spoil something for somebody
▪she wanted to do her own thing, but was afraid of spoiling christmas for the rest of the family.
spoil things
▪ he got very drunk that evening, and seemed determined to spoil things for all of us.

children.name: ruin
children.definition: /ˈruːɪn, ˈruːən/  to completely spoil an event or occasion, with the result that no-one enjoys it:
examples: ▪ how can you prevent stomach upsets from ruining your holiday?
ruin something for somebody
▪ john and sandy argued all the time, which completely ruined the evening for the rest of us.

children.name: mar
children.definition: /mɑːʳ/  if something unpleasant such as an argument or accidentmarsa big or important event, it makes it less enjoyable or less successful:
examples: ▪ outbreaks of fighting and lawlessness marred the new year celebrations.
▪ the race was marred by a horrific accident involving niki lauda.

children.name: put a damper on
children.definition: /ˌpʊt ə ˈdæmpər ɒn/  if bad news, bad weather etcputs a damper onsomething, especially on a social event such as a party, it spoils people’s enjoyment of it:
examples: ▪ the bad news put a damper on the celebrations.
▪ torrential rain put a damper on the event, sending bedraggled guests squelching across lawns to seek shelter.

children.name: cast a shadow over
children.definition: /ˌkɑːst ə ˈʃædəʊ əʊvəʳǁˌkæst-/  if somethingcasts a shadow overan event, period of time etc, it makes people feel less happy or hopeful because they are worrying about it:
examples: ▪ the threat of war cast a shadow over the summer of 1939.
▪ this argument with kuroda did, i must admit, cast a shadow over my mood.
